questions.text: Branches of left coronary artery are all of the following except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Posterior Interventricular Branch The posterior interventricular branch (also known as the posterior descending artery) is not a branch of the left coronary artery. Instead, it typically arises from the right coronary artery (in most individuals), and supplies the posterior part of the interventricular septum and the inferior wall of the left ventricle. The left coronary artery primarily gives rise to branches that supply the anterior and lateral parts of the heart, but the posterior interventricular branch is generally not one of them. Therefore, option (C) is the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (A) Anterior Interventricular Branch The anterior interventricular branch (also known as the left anterior descending artery, LAD) is a major branch of the left coronary artery. It supplies the anterior wall of the left ventricle, the anterior part of the interventricular septum, and parts of the right ventricle. The LAD is a crucial vessel for the heart's blood supply, making option (A) incorrect. (B) Left Diagonal Artery The left diagonal artery is another branch of the left coronary artery. It arises from the left anterior descending (LAD) artery and supplies the anterior wall of the left ventricle. It is an important vessel for blood flow to the heart's left side, so option (B) is incorrect. (D) Left Atrial Artery The left atrial artery is also a branch of the left coronary artery. It supplies blood to the left atrium and contributes to the vascularization of the atrial myocardium. This artery is part of the vascular system of the left side of the heart,

questions.text: Posterior interventricular artery is a branch of the artery -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Right Coronary The posterior interventricular artery (also known as the posterior descending artery) typically arises from the right coronary artery in most individuals. This artery runs in the posterior interventricular sulcus, supplying blood to the posterior portion of the interventricular septum and parts of the left and right ventricles. Therefore, option (C) is the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (A) Circumflex The circumflex artery is a branch of the left coronary artery, and it runs along the left atrioventricular groove. It does not give rise to the posterior interventricular artery, which typically arises from the right coronary artery. Thus, option (A) is incorrect. (B) Left Coronary The left coronary artery supplies the left side of the heart, and its branches include the left anterior descending artery and the circumflex artery. While the left coronary artery supplies the anterior part of the interventricular septum, it does not typically give rise to the posterior interventricular artery. Therefore, option (B) is incorrect. (D) None of the Above Since the posterior interventricular artery is a branch of the right coronary artery, option (D) is incorrect.

questions.text: The following form the boundaries of Koch's triangle except –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Origin of Left Coronary Artery Koch's triangle is an important anatomical area in the right atrium, defined by specific boundaries that are used in the context of electrophysiology and in procedures like ablation. The boundaries of Koch's triangle are: The tendon of Todaro (an important fibrous structure in the right atrium), The septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve (a part of the tricuspid valve), The orifice of the coronary sinus (the opening into the right atrium where the coronary sinus drains). The origin of the left coronary artery (option D) is not a part of Koch's triangle. The left coronary artery originates from the left aortic sinus and is located outside of Koch's triangle, which makes it the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (A) Tendon of Todaro The tendon of Todaro is a fibrous structure in the right atrium, and it forms one of the boundaries of Koch's triangle. It runs from the orifice of the coronary sinus to the septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve. Therefore, option (A) is incorrect as it is part of the boundary of Koch's triangle. (B) Septal Leaflet of Tricuspid Valve The septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve is another important boundary of Koch's triangle. It lies along the septal side of the right atrium and is used in identifying the triangle during procedures. Therefore, option (B) is incorrect as it is part of Koch's triangle. (C) Orifice of Coronary Sinus The orifice of the coronary sinus is located in the right atrium and forms one of the boundaries of Koch's triangle. It is important for identifying the triangle in the context of electrophysiology and other clinical procedures.

questions.text: Fossa ovalis closes because of fussion of-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Septum Primum + Septum Secundum The fossa ovalis closes due to the fusion of the septum primum and the septum secundum in the fetal heart. During embryonic development, the septum primum grows towards the endocardial cushion and eventually fuses with the septum secundum, forming a structure that closes the foramen ovale. The fossa ovalis is the remnant of the foramen ovale after birth, and this fusion helps seal the opening between the atria, preventing blood flow from the right atrium to the left atrium postnatally. Therefore, option (C) is the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (A) Septum Primum + Endocardial Cushion While the septum primum does fuse with the endocardial cushion in the early stages of heart development, this fusion alone does not result in the closure of the fossa ovalis. The closure of the foramen ovale is primarily due to the interaction between the septum primum and the septum secundum, not just the septum primum and endocardial cushion. Therefore, option (A) is incorrect. (B) Septum Secundum + Endocardial Cushion The septum secundum and endocardial cushion do not fuse to directly close the fossa ovalis. While both structures play roles in the partitioning of the atria, it is the fusion between the septum primum and septum secundum that leads to the closure of the foramen ovale. The endocardial cushion helps in the development of the atrioventricular septum, but it is not directly responsible for the closure of the fossa ovalis. Therefore, option (B) is incorrect. (D) Septum Primum + Ostium Primum The septum primum and ostium primum refer to different structures. The ostium primum is an early opening between the atria that later closes as the septum primum grows and fuses with the endocardial cushion, leading to the formation of the ostium secundum and ultimately the closure of the foramen ovale. The fusion of the septum primum and septum secundum is what actually closes the fossa ovalis.

questions.text: SA node is located -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Subepicardially The SA node (Sinoatrial node) is located in the subepicardial layer of the right atrium, near the opening of the superior vena cava. It is situated just beneath the epicardial surface of the heart. This location allows the SA node to be close to the heart’s surface, facilitating the generation and conduction of electrical impulses that initiate the heartbeat. Therefore, option (C) is the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (A) Epicardially The epicardial layer is the outermost layer of the heart, covering the myocardium. While the SA node is located near the epicardium, it is specifically in the subepicardial region, which is beneath the epicardial layer. Hence, the SA node is not exactly located within the epicardial layer. Therefore, option (A) is incorrect. (B) Intramyocardial The intramyocardial location refers to the position within the muscle tissue (myocardium) of the heart. The SA node is not embedded in the myocardium but is located just beneath the epicardium, not within the heart muscle itself. Therefore, option (B) is incorrect. (D) Endocardially The endocardial layer is the innermost lining of the heart, and the SA node is not located within this layer. The SA node is situated in the subepicardial region of the right atrium, which is external to the endocardium.

questions.text: All the following veins drain into coronary sinus except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Anterior Cardiac Vein The anterior cardiac veins do not drain into the coronary sinus. Instead, they drain directly into the right atrium. These veins are located on the anterior surface of the heart and drain the anterior part of the right ventricle. Unlike other veins that drain into the coronary sinus, the anterior cardiac veins have a direct connection to the right atrium. Therefore, option (D) is the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (A) Great Cardiac Vein The great cardiac vein is one of the major veins of the heart that drains into the coronary sinus. It runs along with the anterior interventricular artery and collects deoxygenated blood from the anterior heart and parts of the left ventricle and atrium. Therefore, option (A) is incorrect. (B) Middle Cardiac Vein The middle cardiac vein also drains into the coronary sinus. It runs along the posterior interventricular sulcus and drains deoxygenated blood from the posterior part of the heart, including the posterior interventricular septum and parts of the right and left ventricles. Therefore, option (B) is incorrect. (C) Small Cardiac Vein The small cardiac vein drains into the coronary sinus. It travels along the right margin of the heart and collects deoxygenated blood from the right atrium and right ventricle.

questions.text: The oblique sinus of pericardium lies -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Behind the Left Atrium The oblique sinus of the pericardium is located behind the left atrium of the heart. It is a potential space formed by the reflection of the serous pericardium around the great vessels, specifically the pulmonary veins and the inferior vena cava, and it lies posterior to the left atrium. This space is part of the pericardial cavity and plays a role in allowing the heart to expand and contract. Therefore, option (A) is the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (B) Behind the Ascending Aorta The ascending aorta lies in front of the oblique sinus, not behind it. The oblique sinus is situated more posteriorly in relation to the left atrium, while the ascending aorta is located anteriorly, near the base of the heart. Hence, option (B) is incorrect. (C) Behind the SVC The superior vena cava (SVC) is located anterior and to the right of the heart, and it does not form the boundary of the oblique sinus. The oblique sinus is posterior to the left atrium, not behind the SVC. Therefore, option (C) is incorrect. (D) Anterior to Pulmonary Trunk The pulmonary trunk is located anteriorly to the heart, but the oblique sinus is located posteriorly behind the left atrium. Therefore, the oblique sinus is not anterior to the pulmonary trunk.

questions.text: Branches of R.C.A. (Rt. Coronary artery) -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acute Marginal The right coronary artery (RCA) gives rise to the acute marginal artery, which is an important branch that runs along the lower border of the right ventricle. This branch helps supply blood to the right ventricle and the inferior wall of the heart. Therefore, option (B) is the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (A) Obtuse Marginal The obtuse marginal artery is a branch of the left circumflex artery, not the right coronary artery. It supplies blood to the lateral wall of the left ventricle. Therefore, option (A) is incorrect. (C) Anterior Interventricular The anterior interventricular artery (also known as the left anterior descending artery) is a branch of the left coronary artery (LCA), not the right coronary artery. It supplies the anterior part of the heart and interventricular septum. Therefore, option (C) is incorrect. (D) Diagonal The diagonal artery is a branch of the left anterior descending artery (LAD), which is part of the left coronary system, not the right coronary artery. It supplies the anterior wall of the left ventricle.

questions.text: The middle cardiac vein is located at the -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Posterior Interventricular Sulcus The middle cardiac vein is located in the posterior interventricular sulcus (also known as the posterior longitudinal sulcus), which runs along the back of the heart, near the interventricular septum. The middle cardiac vein collects blood from the posterior part of the heart, draining areas that are supplied by the posterior interventricular artery (a branch of the right coronary artery). Therefore, option (B) is the correct answer. Incorrect Options: (A) Anterior Interventricular Sulcus The anterior interventricular sulcus is located on the front of the heart, where the anterior interventricular artery (left anterior descending artery) runs. The veins associated with this region are the great cardiac vein and anterior cardiac veins, not the middle cardiac vein. Therefore, option (A) is incorrect. (C) Posterior AV Groove The posterior AV groove (also known as the posterior atrioventricular groove) is located between the atria and ventricles on the posterior side of the heart. The vein in this region is the coronary sinus, which collects blood from veins like the great cardiac vein, middle cardiac vein, and small cardiac vein. The middle cardiac vein is not primarily located in this groove but rather in the posterior interventricular sulcus. Therefore, option (C) is incorrect. (D) Anterior AV Groove The anterior AV groove (anterior atrioventricular groove) is located between the atria and ventricles on the front of the heart, where the great cardiac vein runs. The middle cardiac vein is not associated with this groove.

choices.text: Carotid branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve
Vagus nerve and recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.text: In angina pectoris, the pain radiating down the left arm is mediated by increased activity in afferent (sensory) fibers contained in the -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Thoracic Splanchnic Nerve In angina pectoris, pain radiates down the left arm due to referred pain mediated by the thoracic splanchnic nerves. These nerves carry afferent fibers from the heart to the spinal cord, specifically from the T1 to T4 levels. Because the heart and the left arm share the same spinal cord segments, the brain misinterprets the heart's pain as coming from the left arm. This is why the pain from angina pectoris is often felt in the left arm. Therefore, option (D) is correct. Incorrect Options: (A) Carotid Branch of the Glossopharyngeal Nerve The carotid branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (also known as the nerve of Hering) is involved in transmitting sensory information from the carotid body (for chemoreception) and carotid sinus (for baroreception), but it is not responsible for transmitting pain from the heart. Therefore, option (A) is incorrect. (B) Phrenic Nerve The phrenic nerve provides sensory innervation to the diaphragm and parts of the pericardium, but it does not mediate the pain associated with angina pectoris. While it may be involved in other types of chest pain (e.g., diaphragmatic irritation), it is not responsible for the referred pain to the left arm seen in angina. Therefore, option (B) is incorrect. (C) Vagus Nerve and Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve The vagus nerve and recurrent laryngeal nerve primarily supply parasympathetic fibers to the heart and are involved in regulating heart rate. While they contribute to autonomic control, they do not carry pain sensation from the heart. The sensory fibers from the heart travel through the thoracic splanchnic nerves, not the vagus. Therefore, option (C) is incorrect.

questions.text: Autonomic supply to S.A node is–
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Sympathetic Excitatory The autonomic supply to the S.A. (sinoatrial) node is primarily sympathetic excitatory. Sympathetic nerve fibers release norepinephrine, which binds to beta-1 adrenergic receptors on the S.A. node. This increases the heart rate by accelerating the depolarization of the pacemaker cells, thus increasing the overall rate of action potentials (chronotropy). Therefore, the sympathetic system acts in an excitatory manner, increasing heart rate. This makes option (B) correct. Incorrect Options: (A) Parasympathetic Excitatory While the parasympathetic nervous system does supply the S.A. node via the vagus nerve, it is not excitatory. Instead, the parasympathetic system inhibits the heart rate by releasing acetylcholine, which binds to muscarinic receptors, slowing down the depolarization of pacemaker cells. This leads to a decrease in heart rate. Therefore, option (A) is incorrect. (C) Both Excitatory This option is incorrect because although the sympathetic system is excitatory, the parasympathetic system is inhibitory to the S.A. node. Thus, both systems do not exert excitatory effects simultaneously on the S.A. node. Therefore, option (C) is incorrect. (D) Both Inhibitory This option is incorrect as well. While the parasympathetic nervous system is inhibitory, the sympathetic nervous system is excitatory. Both systems do not exert inhibitory effects on the S.A. node at the same time.

questions.text: The base of the heart is formed by the-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Left atrium. The base of the heart is primarily formed by the left atrium, which is the posterior part of the heart. It faces the vertebral column and is located behind the right atrium and the left ventricle. The left atrium receives oxygenated blood from the lungs via the pulmonary veins and contributes to the overall posterior and superior part of the heart, which is known as its base. Incorrect responses: A. Right atrium: The right atrium is located anteriorly and to the right of the left atrium, but it does not form the base of the heart. It is more involved in the right side of the heart and pumps deoxygenated blood into the right ventricle. C. Left ventricle: The left ventricle forms the apex (the pointed end) of the heart, not the base. The left ventricle is the chamber responsible for pumping oxygenated blood to the body via the aorta. D. Right ventricle: The right ventricle forms part of the anterior surface of the heart, but it does not contribute to the base. Like the left ventricle, it also forms part of the heart's overall structure, but it is located inferiorly and anteriorly, not at the base.

choices.text: It is supplied by left coronary artery mainly
Generates an impulse at the rate of about 70/min and initiates the heart beat

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding SA node-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Generates an impulse at the rate of about 70/min and initiates the heart beat. The SA node (Sinoatrial node) is the natural pacemaker of the heart, located in the right atrium near the opening of the superior vena cava. It generates electrical impulses at a rate of approximately 70 beats per minute (though it can vary), initiating the heart's rhythm and regulating its beats by stimulating atrial contraction. This makes it the primary source for the heart's electrical impulses and the initiation of the heartbeat. Incorrect responses: A. It is supplied by left coronary artery mainly: This statement is incorrect because the SA node is primarily supplied by the right coronary artery (in most individuals), not the left. The right coronary artery gives off a branch, the sinuatrial nodal artery, which supplies the SA node. C. Situated in left atrium: This is incorrect. The SA node is located in the right atrium, not the left. Specifically, it is near the opening of the superior vena cava. D. Part of valves: This is also incorrect. The SA node is not part of the heart valves. It is a specialized group of pacemaker cells located in the right atrium, while the heart valves are structures that regulate blood flow between the heart chambers.

choices.text: Coronary sinus opens into right atrium
Vena cardie minimi drains into surface of heart
SA node is supplied by Right coronary artery
Left auricle projects anteriorly to overlap the infundibulum of the right ventricle

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding heart except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Vena cordis minimae drains into surface of heart. This statement is incorrect because the vena cordis minimae (also known as the Thebesian veins) drain directly into the chambers of the heart, primarily into the right atrium and right ventricle, not into the surface of the heart. These veins are small veins that collect deoxygenated blood from the myocardium. Incorrect responses: A. Coronary sinus opens into right atrium: This statement is correct. The coronary sinus, which collects deoxygenated blood from the heart's coronary circulation, opens into the right atrium near the lower part of the interatrial septum. This is a well-known anatomical feature of the heart. C. SA node is supplied by Right coronary artery: This statement is correct. The SA node (Sinoatrial node), which initiates the heart's electrical impulses, is typically supplied by a branch of the right coronary artery in most individuals. This ensures its proper function and blood supply. D. Left auricle projects anteriorly to overlap the infundibulum of the right ventricle: This statement is correct. The left auricle (or left atrial appendage) projects anteriorly and slightly to the left, overlapping the infundibulum of the right ventricle. This anatomical feature is part of the heart's structure and arrangement.

choices.text: Posterior part of the interventricular septum
Anterior wall of the left ventricle

questions.text: Occlusion of the LAD will lead to infarction of which area-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Anterior wall of the left ventricle. The left anterior descending (LAD) artery, a branch of the left coronary artery, supplies the anterior wall of the left ventricle and the anterior part of the interventricular septum. An occlusion of the LAD would cause infarction in this area due to the disruption of blood supply. This is one of the most common sites for myocardial infarction, often referred to as the "widowmaker" due to its severity. Incorrect responses: A. Posterior part of the interventricular septum: This is incorrect because the posterior part of the interventricular septum is primarily supplied by the posterior descending artery (PDA), which is a branch of the right coronary artery (in most individuals) or sometimes from the left circumflex artery. An occlusion of the LAD affects the anterior part of the interventricular septum, not the posterior part. C. Lateral part of the heart: This is incorrect. The lateral part of the heart (the left ventricle) is primarily supplied by the left circumflex artery (LCX), not the LAD. While the LAD supplies the anterior wall and interventricular septum, the lateral wall is mostly supplied by the LCX. D. Inferior surface of right ventricle: This is incorrect because the right ventricle is mainly supplied by the right coronary artery (RCA). The inferior surface of the right ventricle is more associated with occlusion of the RCA or its branches, not the LAD.

questions.text: Anterior intercostal artery is branch of -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Internal mammary artery. The anterior intercostal arteries are branches of the internal mammary artery (also known as the internal thoracic artery). The internal mammary artery, which arises from the subclavian artery, gives off branches that supply the anterior intercostal spaces (typically for the upper 6 intercostal spaces). These arteries are crucial in providing blood supply to the anterior chest wall, including the muscles and skin. Incorrect responses: B. Direct branch of aorta: The aorta primarily gives rise to the posterior intercostal arteries, not the anterior intercostal arteries. The anterior intercostals are supplied by branches from the internal mammary artery, making this an incorrect option. C. Posterior intercostal artery: The posterior intercostal arteries arise directly from the thoracic aorta, not from the anterior side. They run in the posterior part of the intercostal space, which is different from the anterior intercostal arteries. D. Subclavian artery: While the subclavian artery gives rise to the internal mammary artery (which supplies the anterior intercostals), the subclavian artery itself does not directly give rise to the anterior intercostal arteries.

questions.text: All of the following arteries are common sites of occlusion by a thrombus except -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Marginal. The marginal artery is not typically a site of occlusion by a thrombus compared to the other arteries listed. The marginal artery (also called the artery of Drummond) is a vessel that runs along the inner border of the colon, and while it can be affected by certain vascular diseases, it is not commonly involved in coronary artery occlusion, which is what this question is referring to.

choices.text: Is located at the right border of the ascending aorta
It contains specilized nodal cardiac muscle
It is supplied by the atrial branches of the right coronary artery

questions.text: The following statements are true regarding the S A node except -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Is located at the right border of the ascending aorta. This statement is incorrect because the SA node (Sinoatrial node) is not located at the right border of the ascending aorta. Instead, it is situated at the junction of the right atrium and the superior vena cava near the right upper corner of the atrial septum. It is located at the superior part of the right atrium, which is in proximity to the right atrial appendage, not at the ascending aorta. Incorrect responses: B. It contains specialized nodal cardiac muscle: This statement is correct. The SA node is composed of specialized nodal cardiac muscle cells that are capable of generating spontaneous action potentials. These cells have automaticity, meaning they can initiate impulses that control the heart rate, leading to the rhythmic contractions of the heart. C. It is supplied by the atrial branches of the right coronary artery: This statement is correct. The SA node is typically supplied by the right coronary artery (RCA), specifically by its atrial branches. The RCA provides blood supply to various structures of the heart, including the SA node in most individuals, although in some cases, the left coronary artery may contribute to its blood supply. D. It initiates cardiac conduction: This statement is correct. The SA node is known as the natural pacemaker of the heart. It generates the electrical impulses that initiate the cardiac conduction system, which coordinates the contraction of the heart. The impulse generated by the SA node is transmitted through the atria, reaching the AV node, and then spreads through the bundle of His and Purkinje fibers to stimulate ventricular contraction.

choices.text: Lies in anterior part of the coronary sulcus
Has venae cordis minimae as its tributaries
Develops from right anterior cardinal vein

questions.text: The coronary sinus -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ends in right atrium. The coronary sinus is a large vein located on the posterior part of the heart, specifically in the coronary sulcus. It collects deoxygenated blood from the myocardium and drains into the right atrium. It opens into the right atrium, just to the right of the atrioventricular (AV) septum. Therefore, option B is the correct statement, as it accurately describes the drainage of the coronary sinus. Incorrect responses: A. Lies in anterior part of the coronary sulcus: This statement is incorrect. The coronary sinus is located in the posterior part of the coronary sulcus (groove) on the posterior aspect of the heart, not the anterior part. It runs along the atrioventricular (AV) groove and receives blood from most of the coronary veins. C. Has venae cordis minimae as its tributaries: This statement is incorrect. The vena cordis minimae (or small cardiac veins) drain directly into the right atrium and not into the coronary sinus. The coronary sinus receives blood from larger veins such as the great cardiac vein, middle cardiac vein, and small cardiac vein, but not from the venae cordis minimae. D. Develops from right anterior cardinal vein: This statement is incorrect. The coronary sinus does not develop from the right anterior cardinal vein. It actually develops from the left horn of the sinus venosus during embryological development. The right anterior cardinal vein contributes to the formation of the superior vena cava, but not the coronary sinus.

questions.text: Which of the following structures constitutes part of ventricle of heart-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Trabeculae carneae. Trabeculae carneae are muscular ridges found on the inner surface of the ventricles of the heart, specifically in the right and left ventricles. These structures help in the contraction and conduction of the heart muscles and assist in the efficient pumping of blood. They are an integral part of the ventricular anatomy and contribute to the formation of the ventricles' internal structure. Incorrect responses: A. Auricle: The auricle is not part of the ventricle. It refers to a small, ear-shaped extension of the atrium of the heart. Each atrium has an auricle that increases its capacity. Therefore, option A is incorrect because the auricle is part of the atrium, not the ventricle. B. Crista terminalis: The crista terminalis is a smooth muscular ridge found in the right atrium, specifically marking the boundary between the smooth and rough parts of the atrial wall. It does not constitute part of the ventricle, so option B is incorrect. C. Fossa ovalis: The fossa ovalis is a depression found in the interatrial septum of the heart, specifically in the right atrium. It represents the site of the fetal foramen ovale, which allows blood to bypass the non-functioning fetal lungs. It is not found in the ventricles,

choices.text: Arch of aorta in between left common carotid artery and left subclavian artery

questions.text: Fate of 6th aortic arch:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ductus arteriosus. During fetal development, the 6th aortic arch contributes to the formation of the ductus arteriosus, a vital vessel that connects the pulmonary trunk to the aortic arch. The ductus arteriosus allows blood to bypass the non-functioning fetal lungs, which are not yet involved in oxygen exchange. After birth, the ductus arteriosus typically closes and becomes the ligamentum arteriosum. Incorrect responses: A. Arch of aorta in between left common carotid artery and left subclavian artery: This refers to the branching pattern of the aortic arch that involves the left common carotid artery and left subclavian artery. These arteries are derived from the 3rd and 4th aortic arches, respectively. Therefore, option A is incorrect as the 6th aortic arch does not directly contribute to the formation of these arteries. C. Right brachiocephalic: The right brachiocephalic artery arises from the right 4th aortic arch, not the 6th. The right side of the aortic arch forms the brachiocephalic artery, which then bifurcates into the right common carotid and right subclavian arteries. Option C is therefore incorrect. D. Left subclavian artery: The left subclavian artery is derived from the left 4th aortic arch, not the 6th. It arises directly from the aortic arch, not from the ductus arteriosus or any structure related to the 6th arch.

questions.text: In a case of chest pain with pericarditis and pericardial effussion, pain is referred by -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Phrenic nerve A. Phrenic nerve: The phrenic nerve (C3, C4, C5) is responsible for carrying sensory innervation from the fibrous pericardium and the parietal layer of the serous pericardium, which are the pain-sensitive layers of the pericardium. In pericarditis, inflammation of these layers stimulates the phrenic nerve, leading to referred pain that is typically experienced in the shoulder and neck regions because the phrenic nerve shares its spinal segments with the dermatomes of these areas. This makes the phrenic nerve the correct answer. Explanation for the Incorrect Options: B. Superficial cardiac plexus: The superficial cardiac plexus provides autonomic innervation to the heart, mainly regulating cardiac function such as heart rate and force of contraction. It is not involved in transmitting pain from the pericardium, making this option incorrect. C. Deep cardiac plexus: Similar to the superficial cardiac plexus, the deep cardiac plexus provides autonomic control to the heart and does not mediate sensory pain from the pericardium. This option is also incorrect. D. Vagus nerve: The vagus nerve provides parasympathetic innervation to the heart and visceral organs but is not involved in carrying pain signals from the pericardium. Pain from pericarditis is somatic in nature and transmitted via the phrenic nerve, not the vagus nerve. Hence,

questions.text: If circumflex artery gives the posterior interventricular branch, this circulation is described as –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Left dominance. In a heart with left dominance, the circumflex artery (a branch of the left coronary artery) gives rise to the posterior interventricular branch (also known as the posterior descending artery). This means that the left coronary artery, through its circumflex branch, supplies both the left ventricle and the posterior interventricular septum, typically supplied by the right coronary artery in right-dominant hearts. Left dominance occurs in approximately 10-15% of the population. Incorrect Answers: A. Right dominance: In right dominance, the posterior interventricular branch is supplied by the right coronary artery, not the circumflex artery. This is the most common circulation pattern, where the right coronary artery provides blood to the posterior interventricular septum and the right ventricle. C. Codominance: In codominance, both the right and left coronary arteries supply the posterior interventricular septum. This occurs when the right coronary artery and the circumflex artery both contribute to the posterior descending artery. It is a less common variant than right or left dominance. D. Undetermined: This option is incorrect because the dominance pattern is determined based on which artery gives rise to the posterior interventricular branch. It is not undetermined, as it follows clear anatomical rules based on the coronary artery anatomy.

questions.text: Direct opening in the right atrium with -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anterior cardiac vein. The anterior cardiac veins are unique because they drain blood directly into the right atrium, bypassing the coronary sinus. These veins collect blood from the right ventricle and empty directly into the right atrium, making them the only veins with a direct opening into the right atrium. Incorrect Answers: B. Oblique vein: The oblique vein (also called the vein of Marshall) does not open directly into the right atrium. It drains into the coronary sinus, which then empties into the right atrium, so it does not have a direct opening into the right atrium. C. Middle cardiac vein: The middle cardiac vein drains the posterior part of the heart and empties into the coronary sinus, not directly into the right atrium. It is one of the veins that contributes to the venous return through the coronary sinus. D. Great cardiac vein: The great cardiac vein also drains into the coronary sinus and not directly into the right atrium. It collects blood from the anterior portion of the heart and travels alongside the left anterior descending artery before entering the coronary sinus.

questions.text: Fibrous pericardium is attached to -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Central tendon. The fibrous pericardium is the tough outer layer of the pericardium, which surrounds and protects the heart. It is attached to the central tendon of the diaphragm. This attachment helps anchor the heart and pericardial sac to the diaphragm, ensuring stability during respiratory movements. The central tendon acts as a point of attachment for the pericardium and provides support for the heart's position within the thoracic cavity. Incorrect Answers: B. Right crus: The right crus is a part of the diaphragm, but the fibrous pericardium does not attach directly to it. Instead, the fibrous pericardium is more directly attached to the central tendon of the diaphragm, not the crura of the diaphragm. C. Left crus: Similarly, the left crus is another part of the diaphragm but does not serve as the primary attachment point for the fibrous pericardium. The central tendon is the main point of attachment for the pericardium, rather than the crura. D. Pleura: The pleura is the membrane that covers the lungs and lines the thoracic cavity. The fibrous pericardium does not attach to the pleura. While both the pleura and the pericardium are located in the thoracic cavity, they are separate structures and do not have direct attachments to one another.

questions.text: Boundary of triangle of auscultation is not formed by-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Serratus anterior. The boundary of the triangle of auscultation is formed by the scapula, trapezius, and latissimus dorsi, but not the serratus anterior. The triangle of auscultation is a small, triangular area on the posterior chest wall that is formed by the muscles of the upper back and is an ideal location for listening to lung sounds with a stethoscope. The serratus anterior does not contribute to the formation of the triangle, as it lies more laterally on the rib cage and does not form part of the boundaries of this anatomical region. Now, let's look at the incorrect responses: B. Scapula: The scapula forms one of the boundaries of the triangle of auscultation. Specifically, it forms the medial boundary of the triangle, where the edge of the scapula is adjacent to the muscles of the back. This bony landmark provides a point of reference for the triangle’s borders. C. Trapezius: The trapezius muscle is another key contributor to the boundary of the triangle of auscultation. It forms the superior boundary, or the top border, of the triangle. The trapezius is a large muscle that covers the upper back and neck, and its lower part helps to outline the superior boundary of this triangular area. D. Latissimus dorsi: The latissimus dorsi muscle contributes to the lateral boundary of the triangle of auscultation. This muscle is located on the lower part of the back, and its medial border helps form the triangle. Its role is crucial in outlining the lower edge of the triangle, making it a necessary structure for defining the area.

choices.text: Left gastric vein and thoracic duct

questions.text: Aortic hiatus contains –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Azygos vein and thoracic duct. The aortic hiatus is an opening in the diaphragm through which several structures pass from the thoracic cavity into the abdominal cavity. Specifically, the azygos vein and the thoracic duct pass through the aortic hiatus. The azygos vein drains the posterior thoracic wall and abdominal wall and enters the superior vena cava, while the thoracic duct is the main lymphatic vessel that drains lymph from the body into the venous system at the junction of the left subclavian and internal jugular veins. Now, let's look at the incorrect responses: A. Left gastric vein and thoracic duct: The left gastric vein does not pass through the aortic hiatus. Instead, it drains the stomach and part of the esophagus and enters the portal vein. The thoracic duct does pass through the aortic hiatus, but the left gastric vein is not involved in this structure. B. Thoracic duct and hemiazygos vein: While the thoracic duct does pass through the aortic hiatus, the hemiazygos vein does not. The hemiazygos vein drains the left side of the thoracic wall and also drains into the azygos vein, but it passes through the diaphragm at a different location, not through the aortic hiatus. D. Left vagus and thoracic duct: The left vagus nerve does not pass through the aortic hiatus. It travels through the thoracic cavity and contributes to the formation of the esophageal plexus, but it enters the abdomen at the esophageal hiatus, not the aortic hiatus. The thoracic duct, however, does pass through the aortic hiatus as mentioned.

questions.text: Left sided superior vena cava drains into -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Coronary sinus The left-sided superior vena cava (LSVC) is a rare vascular anomaly caused by persistence of the left cardinal vein during embryogenesis. In most cases, the LSVC drains into the coronary sinus, which is located in the posterior aspect of the heart. The coronary sinus then empties into the right atrium, allowing the deoxygenated blood from the left side of the upper body to join systemic venous circulation. This is the most common drainage pattern for an LSVC, making it the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (A) Right atrium This option is incorrect because the LSVC does not typically drain directly into the right atrium. The venous blood from the LSVC passes through the coronary sinus before reaching the right atrium. Direct drainage into the right atrium is an exceptionally rare variant. (B) Left atrium This option is incorrect as it represents a less common and clinically significant variant. When the LSVC drains into the left atrium, it creates a right-to-left shunt, potentially leading to cyanosis and other complications. However, this anomaly is much less frequent than drainage into the coronary sinus. (D) Pericardial space This option is incorrect because the pericardial space is not a functional part of the vascular system. The pericardial space is a potential space between the visceral and parietal layers of the pericardium and does not receive venous blood flow.

questions.text: Which of the following accompanies the anterior interventricular artery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Great cardiac vein The great cardiac vein is the primary vein that accompanies the anterior interventricular artery (also known as the left anterior descending artery, LAD). This vein runs in the anterior interventricular groove alongside the artery, collecting deoxygenated blood from the anterior aspect of the heart, particularly the left ventricle and interventricular septum. The close anatomical relationship between the great cardiac vein and the anterior interventricular artery is a key feature of coronary circulation. The vein eventually drains into the coronary sinus, which empties into the right atrium. Incorrect Responses: (B) Middle cardiac vein This option is incorrect because the middle cardiac vein accompanies the posterior interventricular artery, not the anterior interventricular artery. It runs in the posterior interventricular groove and drains blood from the posterior aspect of the heart. (C) Small cardiac vein This option is incorrect because the small cardiac vein is associated with the right coronary artery. It runs along the right margin of the heart and is not related to the anterior interventricular artery. (D) Right marginal vein This option is incorrect as the right marginal vein accompanies the right marginal artery, a branch of the right coronary artery. It drains blood from the right border of the heart and does not have any direct association with the anterior interventricular artery.

questions.text: Which of the following is not supplied by the right coronary artery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Right bundle branch The right bundle branch is not typically supplied by the right coronary artery. It is predominantly supplied by the left anterior descending artery (LAD), a branch of the left coronary artery. The LAD provides blood to most of the interventricular septum, where the right bundle branch is located. This makes the LAD the primary artery responsible for the blood supply to the conduction system in this area, including the right bundle branch. Incorrect Responses: (A) SA node This option is incorrect because the sinoatrial (SA) node is commonly supplied by a branch of the right coronary artery (RCA) in about 60–70% of individuals. In the remaining cases, it is supplied by the circumflex branch of the left coronary artery. (B) AV node This option is incorrect as the atrioventricular (AV) node is almost always supplied by the RCA via its AV nodal branch. This is true in the majority of cases regardless of the dominance pattern of the coronary arteries. (C) AV bundle This option is incorrect because the AV bundle (or bundle of His) is supplied by both the RCA and the LAD, with the RCA contributing significantly to its proximal portion. Therefore, it is considered to have a blood supply from the RCA in addition to the LAD.

questions.text: Superior vena cava opens into right atrium at the level of -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) T5 The superior vena cava (SVC) opens into the right atrium at the level of the T5 vertebra. The SVC is a major vein that returns deoxygenated blood from the upper body, head, neck, and upper limbs to the heart. It courses through the thorax and drains into the superior part of the right atrium, just behind the third costal cartilage, which corresponds to the T5 vertebral level. This anatomical landmark is crucial in cardiothoracic surgery and imaging. Incorrect Responses: (A) T1 This option is incorrect because the superior vena cava is located much lower in the thorax. At the level of T1, the brachiocephalic veins are still converging to form the superior vena cava, and it has not yet descended to reach the right atrium. (B) T3 This option is incorrect because, at the T3 level, the superior vena cava is still descending in the superior mediastinum. It does not open into the right atrium at this level. (C) T4 This option is incorrect because the superior vena cava passes through the thorax but does not reach the right atrium at T4. The bifurcation of the trachea and the sternal angle are at this level, which is superior to the SVC's entry point into the heart.

questions.text: Aortic area for auscultation overlying the chest wall is located at
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 2nd intercostal space on the right side The aortic area for auscultation is located in the 2nd intercostal space on the right side of the sternum. This is the auscultatory site for the aortic valve because it is where sounds generated by this valve are best transmitted and heard. Although the anatomical location of the aortic valve is at the base of the heart, auscultation sites are determined by the direction of blood flow and sound conduction through the chest wall. This is the primary location for detecting murmurs related to the aortic valve, such as aortic stenosis or aortic regurgitation. Incorrect Responses: (A) Cardiac apex This option is incorrect because the cardiac apex is the auscultation site for the mitral valve, located at the 5th intercostal space at the midclavicular line. It is unrelated to the aortic valve's auscultation. (C) 2nd intercostal space on the left side This option is incorrect because the 2nd intercostal space on the left side is the auscultation site for the pulmonary valve, not the aortic valve. This area transmits sounds associated with pulmonary valve function. (D) Epigastric region This option is incorrect because the epigastric region is not used for auscultating any of the heart valves. It is more commonly examined for abdominal sounds and vascular abnormalities such as an aortic aneurysm but has no relevance to aortic valve auscultation.

questions.text: Sympathetic supply to heart
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) T1-T4 The sympathetic supply to the heart originates from the T1 to T4 spinal segments. Sympathetic fibers from these levels form part of the cardiac plexus, which provides sympathetic innervation to the heart, influencing heart rate, contractility, and conduction. These fibers travel through the sympathetic trunk and synapse in the cervical and upper thoracic ganglia before reaching the heart. The sympathetic stimulation increases heart rate and force of contraction and is involved in the fight-or-flight response. Incorrect Responses: (A) C5-C7 This option is incorrect because the sympathetic supply to the heart does not originate from the cervical spinal levels C5 to C7. The cervical nerves primarily innervate the upper limbs and the neck, not the heart. The sympathetic fibers that affect the heart are located in the thoracic region, specifically between T1 and T4. (C) C1-C4 This option is incorrect because, as with C5-C7, the cervical nerves C1 to C4 are not responsible for the sympathetic supply to the heart. These levels provide sensory and motor innervation to the neck, shoulders, and upper chest, but not to the heart. (D) T5-T9 This option is incorrect because the T5-T9 spinal segments are part of the sympathetic innervation to the abdominal organs and not the heart. These levels contribute to the sympathetic supply of the digestive system, kidneys, and other abdominal structures, but they do not influence the heart's function directly.

questions.text: Floor of Fossa ovalis is a remnant of-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Septum primum The floor of the fossa ovalis is a remnant of the septum primum. During fetal development, the septum primum is the first structure to form in the interatrial septum. It initially forms as a thin membrane that separates the right and left atria. After birth, the septum primum fuses with the septum secundum, and the space between them, known as the foramen ovale, closes. The region of the septum primum that remains after this fusion becomes the floor of the fossa ovalis in the adult heart. Incorrect Responses: (B) Septum secundum This option is incorrect because the septum secundum forms the upper part of the foramen ovale, not the floor. It grows alongside the septum primum but does not form the fossa ovalis floor. After birth, the septum secundum prevents the reopening of the foramen ovale, while the septum primum remains as the floor. (C) Ductus arteriosus This option is incorrect because the ductus arteriosus is a fetal vessel that connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta. It is not related to the formation of the fossa ovalis or its floor. After birth, the ductus arteriosus closes to become the ligamentum arteriosum. (D) Ductus venosus This option is incorrect because the ductus venosus is a fetal vessel that shunts blood from the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava, bypassing the liver. It has no relation to the fossa ovalis or its formation. After birth, the ductus venosus closes and becomes the ligamentum venosum.

questions.text: SA node blood supply is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Right coronary artery The sinoatrial (SA) node is primarily supplied by the right coronary artery (RCA) in about 60-70% of individuals. This artery branches off the RCA and supplies the SA node, which is located in the right atrium. The blood supply to the SA node is crucial for maintaining its function in regulating the heart's rhythm. Variations exist, and in some cases, the SA node may be supplied by the left coronary artery, but the right coronary artery is the most common source. Incorrect Responses: (B) Left coronary artery This option is incorrect because, while the left coronary artery supplies many structures in the heart, it does not typically supply the SA node. The left coronary artery primarily supplies the left atrium, left ventricle, and parts of the interventricular septum, but it is not the primary source of blood for the SA node. (C) Left and descending coronary arteries This option is incorrect because the left and descending coronary arteries do not supply the SA node. The left coronary artery primarily supplies the left side of the heart, and while the left anterior descending artery supplies the anterior wall of the heart, it does not typically provide blood to the SA node. (D) Anterior aortic sinus This option is incorrect because the anterior aortic sinus does not supply the SA node. The sinuses of the aorta (which give rise to the coronary arteries) do not directly supply the SA node; instead, the RCA is the main source of blood for this structure.

questions.text: Occlusion of left anterior descending artery results in ischemia of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anterolateral wall The left anterior descending artery (LAD) is responsible for supplying blood to the anterolateral wall of the left ventricle, as well as the interventricular septum. An occlusion in the LAD can lead to ischemia in these regions. The LAD runs along the anterior surface of the heart and supplies crucial areas involved in left ventricular contraction. As it is the major artery that supplies the anterior and lateral walls of the left ventricle, blockage of the LAD leads to a significant portion of the heart muscle experiencing ischemia. Incorrect Responses: (B) Left atrium This option is incorrect because the left atrium is primarily supplied by the left circumflex artery (LCX), not the LAD. While the LAD does supply a small portion of the left atrium, the majority of its blood supply comes from the LCX. Therefore, an occlusion of the LAD does not primarily affect the left atrium. (C) Right ventricle This option is incorrect because the right ventricle is predominantly supplied by the right coronary artery (RCA). The LAD mainly supplies the left ventricle and parts of the interventricular septum, not the right ventricle. Therefore, an occlusion of the LAD does not lead to ischemia in the right ventricle. (D) Interatrial septum This option is incorrect because the interatrial septum is typically supplied by branches of both the LAD and the RCA. However, in the context of LAD occlusion, the primary area affected would be the anterolateral wall of the left ventricle, not the interatrial septum, which is supplied by a more central location in the coronary circulation.

questions.text: Ductus venosus connects
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Umbilical vein and IVC The ductus venosus is a fetal blood vessel that connects the umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava (IVC). This vessel plays a critical role in fetal circulation by allowing oxygenated blood from the placenta, carried by the umbilical vein, to bypass the liver and flow directly into the IVC. This ensures that oxygen-rich blood is delivered to the heart and brain of the fetus. After birth, the ductus venosus closes and becomes the ligamentum venosum. Incorrect Responses: (A) Pulmonary trunk and descending aorta This option is incorrect because the ductus arteriosus connects the pulmonary trunk to the descending aorta, not the ductus venosus. The ductus arteriosus allows fetal blood to bypass the lungs, which are not yet in use for oxygen exchange before birth. (B) Right atrium and left atrium This option is incorrect because the foramen ovale, not the ductus venosus, connects the right atrium to the left atrium in fetal circulation. The foramen ovale allows oxygenated blood from the placenta to bypass the non-functioning fetal lungs by flowing directly from the right atrium to the left atrium. (D) Pulmonary trunk and ascending aorta This option is incorrect because the ductus arteriosus connects the pulmonary trunk and the descending aorta, not the ascending aorta. The ductus arteriosus allows the blood in the fetal circulation to bypass the lungs and flow directly into the aorta.

questions.text: Fossa ovalis closes because of fusion of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Septum primum + Septum secundum The fossa ovalis is a remnant of the fetal foramen ovale, which allowed blood to bypass the non-functional fetal lungs by flowing directly from the right atrium to the left atrium. The closure of the foramen ovale occurs due to the fusion of the septum primum and septum secundum, which form a seal between the two atria. After birth, the increased blood flow to the lungs causes a pressure change that helps push the septum primum against the septum secundum, leading to the closure of the foramen ovale and the formation of the fossa ovalis. Incorrect Responses: (A) Septum primum + Endocardial cushion This option is incorrect because the endocardial cushions play a role in the formation of the heart valves and septa, but they are not directly involved in the closure of the fossa ovalis. The closure is primarily due to the fusion of the septum primum and the septum secundum, not the endocardial cushion. (B) Septum secundum + Endocardial cushion This option is incorrect because the septum secundum and endocardial cushion are not responsible for the closure of the foramen ovale. While the endocardial cushions are important in the development of other structures, the fusion of the septum primum and septum secundum is what leads to the closure of the fossa ovalis. (D) None This option is incorrect because the fusion of the septum primum and septum secundum is the correct mechanism for the closure of the fossa ovalis. Therefore, "None" does not accurately describe the process.

questions.text: The vein in the cardiac anterior interventricular groove is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Great Cardiac Vein The great cardiac vein runs along the anterior interventricular groove (also known as the anterior descending groove) of the heart. This vein collects deoxygenated blood from the front of the heart, particularly from the left ventricle and the interventricular septum, and eventually drains into the coronary sinus, which empties into the right atrium. The great cardiac vein is the largest of the veins in the anterior interventricular groove and is an important component of the coronary circulation. Incorrect Responses: (B) Anterior cardiac vein This option is incorrect because the anterior cardiac veins are located on the anterior surface of the right ventricle, not in the anterior interventricular groove. They drain directly into the right atrium, bypassing the coronary sinus. They do not run within the anterior interventricular groove. (C) Posterior cardiac vein This option is incorrect because the posterior cardiac vein is found on the posterior surface of the left ventricle, not in the anterior interventricular groove. It drains into the coronary sinus, but it does not run along the anterior interventricular groove. (D) The Besian vein This option is incorrect because the Besian vein is a small vein that drains the myocardium of the right atrium and right ventricle. It is not associated with the anterior interventricular groove. The Besian vein usually drains into the right atrium directly, not into the coronary sinus or along the interventricular grooves.

questions.text: In theright atrium, the limbus fossa ovalis is remnant of -
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Septum secundum The limbus fossa ovalis is a raised ridge found in the right atrium around the fossa ovalis, which is a depression that is the remnant of the fetal foramen ovale. The limbus fossa ovalis is formed by the septum secundum, which is a structure in the fetal heart that contributes to the formation of the foramen ovale. During fetal life, the foramen ovale allowed blood to bypass the lungs, and after birth, the septum secundum helps close this opening. The limbus fossa ovalis represents the upper edge of the septum secundum that once sealed off the foramen ovale. Incorrect Responses: (A) Septum primum This option is incorrect because the septum primum is involved in the initial formation of the foramen ovale in the fetal heart, but it is not directly responsible for the formation of the limbus fossa ovalis. The septum primum is a membrane that initially grows towards the septum secundum and leaves behind the opening (foramen ovale) during fetal circulation. The limbus fossa ovalis specifically represents the septum secundum, not the septum primum. (C) Endocardial cushions This option is incorrect because the endocardial cushions are involved in the formation of the heart valves and the septa between the atria and ventricles, but they do not directly contribute to the limbus fossa ovalis. Endocardial cushions are responsible for the development of the atrioventricular valves and septal formation but not for the foramen ovale or its remnants. (D) Tricuspid valve orifice This option is incorrect because the tricuspid valve orifice is the opening between the right atrium and right ventricle. It is not related to the limbus fossa ovalis. The tricuspid valve orifice is a separate structure that serves as a valve to regulate blood flow between the two chambers and does not have a direct connection to the remnants of the fetal foramen ovale.

questions.text: All the following vessels end directly in the right atrium EXCEPT
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Oblique vein of left atrium The oblique vein of left atrium, also known as the vein of Marshall, does not drain directly into the right atrium. It is a vein that originates from the left atrium and drains into the coronary sinus, which then empties into the right atrium. While the coronary sinus drains directly into the right atrium, the oblique vein of left atrium is an indirect contributor to the venous return to the right atrium through the coronary sinus. Incorrect Responses: (A) Coronary sinus This option is incorrect because the coronary sinus is a large vein that drains directly into the right atrium. It collects deoxygenated blood from the myocardium and empties into the right atrium, making it one of the major veins that drain directly into the right atrium. (C) Anterior cardiac vein This option is incorrect because the anterior cardiac veins drain directly into the right atrium. These veins primarily drain the anterior portion of the right ventricle and empty directly into the right atrium, bypassing the coronary sinus. (D) Venae cordis minimae This option is incorrect because the venae cordis minimae, also known as the Thebesian veins, drain directly into the right atrium. These small veins drain the myocardium of the heart directly into the heart chambers, including the right atrium, contributing to the venous return.

questions.text: All of the following open into Right atrium except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Middle cardiac vein The middle cardiac vein does not open directly into the right atrium. Instead, it drains into the coronary sinus, which then empties into the right atrium. The middle cardiac vein collects deoxygenated blood from the posterior part of the heart and carries it toward the coronary sinus, which ultimately drains into the right atrium. Thus, it is not one of the veins that open directly into the right atrium. Incorrect Responses: (A) Anterior cardiac vein This option is incorrect because the anterior cardiac veins drain directly into the right atrium. These veins drain blood from the anterior wall of the right ventricle and open directly into the right atrium, bypassing the coronary sinus. (B) Venae cordis minimi This option is incorrect because the venae cordis minimi (Thebesian veins) also open directly into the right atrium. These are small veins that drain blood from the myocardium (heart muscle) directly into the chambers of the heart, including the right atrium. (C) Coronary sinus This option is incorrect because the coronary sinus opens directly into the right atrium. The coronary sinus is the main venous drainage system of the heart, collecting deoxygenated blood from the myocardium and draining it into the right atrium.

questions.text: Torus aorticus is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bulge in the atria The torus aorticus is a bulge or prominence in the right atrium. It is formed by the anterior protrusion of the ascending aorta into the right atrium, typically just above the level of the aortic valve. This structure is considered a normal anatomical feature, especially in the fetal heart or during early stages of life, and can be visualized in imaging techniques like echocardiography or angiography. Incorrect Responses: (B) Bulge in aorta This option is incorrect because the torus aorticus is located in the right atrium, not within the aorta. It is the result of the aorta's proximity to the right atrium, but it does not represent a bulge in the aortic wall itself. (C) Aortic wall tear This option is incorrect because the torus aorticus is not related to any tear or rupture in the aortic wall. An aortic wall tear refers to a pathological condition such as an aortic dissection, which is an emergency medical condition, and this is unrelated to the normal anatomical feature of the torus aorticus. (D) Septal defect This option is incorrect because the torus aorticus is not a septal defect. A septal defect refers to an abnormal opening in the septum between the heart chambers (e.g., atrial septal defect or ventricular septal defect), which is a congenital heart condition. The torus aorticus is a normal anatomical structure and not a defect.

questions.text: Third coronary artery is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Conus artery The conus artery is referred to as the third coronary artery. It is a small branch that typically originates from the right coronary artery (RCA), though it can also arise from the left coronary artery in some cases. This artery supplies blood to the right ventricle's outflow tract (the conus arteriosus) and plays a role in the vascularization of the right atrium. Despite being a small vessel, it is considered a third coronary artery due to its distinct location and contribution to the blood supply of the heart. Incorrect Responses: (A) Left anterior descending (LAD) This option is incorrect because the left anterior descending artery is one of the main branches of the left coronary artery (LCA), not the third coronary artery. The LAD supplies blood to the anterior wall of the left ventricle and interventricular septum, but it is not considered the third coronary artery. (B) Left anterior descending (LAD) This option is a repeat of the previous one and is also incorrect for the same reasons. The left anterior descending artery is not the third coronary artery, as explained above. (D) Vieussen's artery This option is incorrect because Vieussen's artery, also known as the anterior right ventricular artery, is a small vessel that can supply the right ventricle. However, it is not the third coronary artery, which is the conus artery. Vieussen's artery is less commonly referred to as a distinct coronary artery compared to the conus artery.

questions.text: S.A. Node is located at ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Upper end of crista terminalis The S.A. node (Sinoatrial node) is located at the upper end of the crista terminalis, which is a ridge in the right atrium of the heart. This node is situated near the junction of the superior vena cava (SVC) and the right atrium. The S.A. node is responsible for initiating the electrical impulses that regulate the heart's rhythm, making it the natural pacemaker of the heart. Its location at the upper end of the crista terminalis is strategically placed to ensure it can efficiently coordinate the heart's electrical activity. Incorrect Responses: (B) Lower end of crista terminalis This option is incorrect because the lower end of the crista terminalis is not the site of the S.A. node. The S.A. node is located at the upper end of the crista terminalis, closer to the superior vena cava. The lower end of the crista terminalis is not associated with the location of the S.A. node. (C) At opening of IVC This option is incorrect because the S.A. node is not located at the opening of the inferior vena cava (IVC). The IVC opens into the right atrium, but the S.A. node is located near the superior vena cava, at the upper end of the crista terminalis, which is far from the IVC opening. (D) At ostium primum This option is incorrect because the ostium primum refers to a structure that was present during fetal development, forming part of the atrioventricular septum before the atrial septum completes its development. The S.A. node is not located near the ostium primum, but rather at the upper end of the crista terminalis in the right atrium.

questions.text: In an embryo, the 4th arch forms?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Aortic arch In embryonic development, the 4th pharyngeal arch forms the aortic arch, which plays a critical role in the arterial system of the developing fetus. Specifically, the left 4th arch forms the arch of the aorta, while the right 4th arch forms the proximal part of the right subclavian artery. The aortic arch is a vital structure that connects the ascending aorta to the descending aorta and gives rise to important arteries supplying the upper body. Incorrect Responses: (B) Left subclavian artery This option is incorrect because the left subclavian artery is derived from the left 7th intersegmental artery and left 4th aortic arch, but the direct formation of the left subclavian artery is not attributed solely to the 4th arch. It is the result of a combination of the left 4th arch and the 7th intersegmental artery, which is distinct from the formation of the aortic arch. (C) Right pulmonary artery This option is incorrect because the right pulmonary artery is formed from the right 6th arch, not the 4th. The 6th arch contributes to the formation of the pulmonary arteries, which supply the lungs. The 4th arch is responsible for the formation of the aortic arch and part of the subclavian arteries. (D) Left pulmonary artery This option is incorrect because the left pulmonary artery is also derived from the left 6th arch, not the 4th. As mentioned, the 6th arch forms both the right and left pulmonary arteries, which are crucial for pulmonary circulation in the fetus.

questions.text: AV node is situated in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Koch's triangle The AV node is located in the right atrium, specifically within Koch's triangle. Koch's triangle is a triangular area on the floor of the right atrium, bordered by the tendon of Todaro, the coronary sinus opening, and the septal leaflet of the tricuspid valve. This anatomical region is where the AV node is located, and it plays a critical role in electrical conduction, ensuring that the atrial impulses are transmitted to the ventricles. Incorrect Responses: (A) Opening of SVC This is incorrect because the opening of the superior vena cava (SVC) is located in the upper part of the right atrium, but the AV node is not located at this site. The SVC's opening is near the upper part of the right atrium and does not relate to the location of the AV node. (B) Interventricular septum This is incorrect because the interventricular septum is located between the right and left ventricles, not in the right atrium where the AV node is situated. The AV node is located in the right atrium, and it plays a role in transmitting electrical impulses from the atria to the ventricles, but not in the interventricular septum itself. (D) None This is incorrect because the correct answer is indeed Koch's triangle

questions.text: True about cardiac muscle is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Large central nucleus Cardiac muscle cells are branched, striated, and contain a single central nucleus. This characteristic allows for efficient conduction of electrical impulses and synchronized contraction throughout the heart. Cardiac muscle cells are connected through intercalated discs, which contain gap junctions, desmosomes, and adherens junctions, allowing communication between cells. Incorrect Responses: (A) Spindle shaped This is incorrect because cardiac muscle cells are not spindle-shaped; they are branching, cylindrical, and striated. Spindle-shaped cells are characteristic of smooth muscle tissue. (C) No gap junctions This is incorrect because cardiac muscle cells do contain gap junctions. Gap junctions allow for the coordinated and rapid transmission of electrical impulses between cells, which is essential for heart contraction and synchronization. (D) Arranged in sheets This is correct because cardiac muscle cells are arranged in sheets or layers within the heart walls. This arrangement allows for efficient pumping of blood and synchronization of contraction across different parts of the heart.

questions.text: Blood supply of ventral 2/3rd of interventricular septum of heart
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Left coronary artery The ventral two-thirds of the interventricular septum of the heart is primarily supplied by the left coronary artery, more specifically, its branch, the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. The LAD artery runs in the anterior interventricular groove and supplies the anterior portion of the interventricular septum, including the septal wall of both ventricles. This is why the correct answer is B, as it provides the blood supply to the majority of the interventricular septum. Incorrect Responses: (A) Right coronary artery The right coronary artery is mainly responsible for supplying the right atrium, right ventricle, and parts of the posterior interventricular septum via the posterior interventricular artery (also known as the posterior descending artery). While the right coronary artery does supply the posterior part of the interventricular septum, it is not responsible for the blood supply of the ventral two-thirds of the septum. Therefore, A is incorrect. (C) Posterior interventricular artery The posterior interventricular artery is a branch of the right coronary artery (in right-dominant coronary circulation) and supplies the posterior third of the interventricular septum. It does not supply the ventral two-thirds of the septum, which is primarily supplied by the left coronary artery, making C incorrect. (D) Marginal artery The marginal artery (also known as the artery of Drummond) is a branch of the left coronary artery that supplies the border of the heart, particularly the lower part of the left ventricle. It does not supply the interventricular septum and is not related to the ventral two-thirds of the interventricular septum. Therefore, D is incorrect.

questions.text: A 53 year old man is brought to emergency department for evaluation of fever, chills & malaise. Cardiac examination reveals a new holo-systolic heart murmur. Blood sample for routine and cultures are obtained & he undergoes transesophageal echocardiography. The ultrasound probe is placed in the mid-esophagus facing anteriorly & cardiac chambers are interrogated. Anatomically which of the following chambers is closest to the probe –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Oesophagus lies behind Left atrium separated by pericardium.

questions.text: A 55 years old man with known history of stable angina comes to Emergency department with complaints of chest pain which is not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. After initial stabilization for 2 days, he undergoes a thallium stress test. Test result shows reduced perfusion of the lateral wall of the left ventricle. Which artery is most likely occluded?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Left circumflex artery supplies lateral wall of the left ventricle

questions.text: A 55 years old male presents with complaints of periodic, burning substernal chest pain A thallium stress test shows hypoperfusion of the cardiac muscle forming the diaphragmatic surface of the heart Which of the following coronary arteries is most likely occluded in this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Right coronary artery. This conclusion is based on the anatomical supply of the heart's blood vessels. The patient's symptoms of periodic, burning chest pain are a classic sign of myocardial ischemia, or reduced blood flow to the heart muscle. The thallium stress test is used to identify areas of the heart with poor blood flow, and in this case, it specifically pinpointed the diaphragmatic surface (also known as the inferior wall) of the heart. The right coronary artery (RCA) is the major vessel responsible for supplying blood to this specific area. Therefore, a blockage in the RCA is the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms and the finding on the stress test.

questions.text: A cyanotic infant was delivered in the emergency room. You found out that her great vessels were transposed and that her ductus arteriosus is needed to be kept open in order to survive. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Prostaglandins are used to keep the ductus arteriosus patent whereas Prostaglandins inhibitor(Indomethacin) is used for the closure of ductus arteriosus.

questions.text: A cyanotic infant was delivered in the emergency room. You found out that her great vessels were transposed. Which of the following would have led to patients cardiac anomaly?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Spiraling of the septum leads to formation of normal connections between great vessels and ventricles and non spiralling will lead to transposition of great vessels.

questions.text: A 2-day-old is diagnosed with transposition of the great arteries. If this condition were to be left untreated, it would be fatal. Which of the following structures must remain patent so that the infant can survive until surgical correction of the malformation?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) In a case of transposition of the great arteries, oxygenated blood travels from the left ventricle into the pulmonary trunk, where it will eventually reach the lungs. In contrast, the aorta would be carrying deoxygenated blood into the systemic circulation. A patent ductus arteriosus acts as a shunt between the aorta and pulmonary trunk, allowing oxygenated and deoxygenated blood to mix and therefore allowing some oxygenated blood to reach the tissues.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with a history of stable angina presents to the emergency department with an episode of chest pain that is not relieved by rest or nitroglycerin. After stabilization in the telemetry unit for 2 days, he undergoes a thallium stress test. The results show reduced perfusion of the lateral wall of the left ventricle. Which artery is most likely occluded?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) In some patients with coronary artery disease, thallium stress tests may be performed instead of cardiac catheterization to determine the vessels involved and the extent of occlusion. The left circumflex (LCx) branch supplies the lateral wall of the left ventricle; in 10% of the population, it also supplies the posterior wall and AV node. The left anterior descending (LAD) branch of the left coronary artery supplies the anterior wall of the left ventricle and the anterior portion of the inter-ventricular septum. The left main coronary artery gives rise to both the LCX and the LAD.

questions.text: A newborn baby is observed to be cyanotic immediately after birth. Diagnostic studies, including an ultrasound, reveal that the baby has persistent truncus arteriosus. Which of the following additional defects is this baby most likely to have?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Persistent truncus arteriosus results from failure of the aorticopulmonary septum to form. Normally, the aorticopulmonary septum divides the truncus arteriosus into the ascending aorta and the pulmonary trunk. The aorticopulmonary septum also contributes to the formation of the membranous portion of the interventricular septum. When the aorticopulmonary septum does not form, the truncus arteriosus persists rather than being divided, and the membranous interventricular septum is incomplete. Because neural crest cells contribute to the formation of the aorticopulmonary septum, it is believed that this defect may result from a defect in migration of neural crest cells.

questions.text: Right coronary artery arises from
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A-Right coronary artery arises from anterior aortic sinus. Option B-Posterior aortic sinus on left side gives rise to left coronary artery. Option C,D-Anterior and Posterior coronary sinus do not give rise to any coronary arteries.

questions.text: The reason for the long course of left recurrent laryngeal Nerve is d/t the persistence of which aortic arch artery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Derivatives of aortic arch:- Arch I - maxillary arteries Arch 2 - hyoid and stapedial arteries Arch 3 - common carotid, and first part of internal carotid arteries Arch 4 -(Left side) - arch of aorta from left common carotid to Left subclavian artery. (Right. side) = right subclavian artery (proximal portion): Arch 6 (left side) - Left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus (right side)- right pulmonary artery. The recurrent laryngeal nerve is a branch of vagus nerve. On the left side, ductus arteriosus is present (6th arch) , So left recurrent laryngeal nerve has to loop around it to cross it where as right recurrent laryngeal nerve can pass straight and doesn’t need to loop around as ductus arteriosus is absent on the right side This the reason for longer course of left recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following arches causes the defect shown in the image?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A-4th right aortic arch gives rise to the proximal part of the right Subclavian artery. Option B-4th left aortic arch gives rise to arch of aorta. Option C-6th right aortic arch forms the proximal part of the right pulmonary artery. Option D-The image shows a patent ductus arteriosus due to a defect in the left side of the 6th pharyngeal arch.

questions.text: Which of the following supplies the marked area as shown in the image:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A-Left Circumflex artery supplies left atrium and left ventricle. Option B-Marked area is supplied by conus artery.It supplies blood flow to the conus, the right ventricular outflow tract and a large portion of the anterior free wall of the right ventricle. Option C-Diagonal artery supplies left ventricle. Option D-Marginal artery supplies right ventricle.
